channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: Volunteers in Kyiv are seen receiving weapons to help repel Russian troops on Saturday. Most of Russia’s forces have entered Ukraine, but they are “increasingly frustrated by their lack of momentum," the Pentagon said. https://t.co/Gck0BFGGh3 https://t.co/y6hIVVxvlI

As Russian troops lay siege to Kyiv, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine appeared on camera on Saturday to offer proof of his continued presence in his country’s capital, praise his outgunned and outmanned military and request international support. https://t.co/ZWxbd7NrFh https://t.co/30yTHUnApM
Road service employees are dismantling road signs across Ukraine in order to complicate navigation for the invading Russian troops. https://t.co/O2zsIDdJGT https://t.co/F8OjqkohAc

The Kremlin is hiding the reality of Russia's attack on Ukraine from its own people, even cracking down on news outlets that call it a “war.” But the truth is that President Vladimir Putin ushered in a crisis for his country, its economy and its identity. https://t.co/mCyjsgRwN0
Breaking News: Ukraine, outmanned and outgunned, has slowed Russia's advance on Kyiv and two other cities as its forces wage a ferocious resistance. https://t.co/9iLFm37Tsc

Russia’s invasion has pushed tens of thousands of Ukrainians out of their homes and fleeing across borders. But unlike refugees from wars in Syria, Iraq and Afghanistan who have sought asylum in Europe over the past decade, they are being welcomed. https://t.co/TN25fzozJs

As the United States and European Union apply sanctions to penalize Russia for its invasion of Ukraine, European companies are bracing for the possibility that the punishment intended for Moscow may affect them, too. https://t.co/Zjfzf8E7Da

The speed of Russia’s advance in Ukraine had slowed by Saturday afternoon, “likely as a result of acute logistical difficulties and strong Ukrainian resistance,” Britain’s Ministry of Defense said in a statement based on intelligence updates. https://t.co/GJCouMAqva

President Volodymyr Zelensky tried to rally his people on Saturday saying that the Ukrainian army still controlled the capital and key cities nearby. “We messed up their plans, they did not gain any advantage over us,” he said. https://t.co/tAOBEunLCf

Videos and photos verified by The New York Times showed a residential building struck by a missile in southwestern Kyiv, about 1.5 miles from Sikorsky Memorial Airport, on Saturday morning. Videos showed rescue and evacuation efforts underway. https://t.co/1930FntITz https://t.co/hHluNLHsIc

Ukrainians arrived in the Polish border village of Medyka on Saturday, as thousands of people flee Russia’s invasion of their country and cross into neighboring nations.
Follow live updates on the war in Ukraine here: https://t.co/HR3g5hT6aC https://t.co/pEqODDV1v0

Julia, a teacher and Ukrainian volunteer, weeps as she waits to be deployed to fight Russian troops around Kyiv on Saturday. Ukrainian civilians have taken up arms and joined the battle to keep control of the capital. https://t.co/dstRTHIW8F https://t.co/Icvw3wb43m

"I’m Ready": Ukraine’s civilians take up arms as volunteer fighters armed with assault rifles patrolled central Kyiv on Friday, poised to defend their country.
Follow live updates. https://t.co/Rk8EBro5BB https://t.co/STbUP29idm

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine posted a video on Twitter on Saturday, telling the public not to believe false reports. He was alive, he said. Kyiv had not fallen. "We are not putting down any arms. We will protect our country," he said. https://t.co/BmuJDA9xyj https://t.co/zSr4MRcp5d
Landmarks in New York, London, Rome and elsewhere use lights as a show of solidarity for the people of Ukraine on Friday night. https://t.co/8TpWNGPXWL https://t.co/KI5EHKS55M

Ukraine’s defense forces waged a ferocious resistance to the Russian invasion on Saturday, battling to keep control of the capital, Kyiv. There was intense street fighting and bursts of gunfire and explosions across the city.
Follow the latest: https://t.co/r0tiZtJiOX https://t.co/5Fuphg6l2c
Videos and photos verified by The New York Times showed an apartment building struck by a missile in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Saturday morning. https://t.co/L2X5rlBKLG
More than 50,000 Ukrainians have fled the country so far, the UN High Commissioner for Refugees said on Friday, and the agency believes as many as 100,000 have been displaced. https://t.co/Cw3xxpI4L1

Germany is delivering 5,000 helmets to Ukraine’s Army, a military spokesman said on Saturday, a move that has been widely ridiculed as a meager commitment to the country’s defense in the face of Russia’s military might. https://t.co/zqKuzHsOtr

The Biden administration intends to impose sanctions on President Vladimir Putin, taking the rare step of freezing the personal assets of a world leader, people familiar with the matter said on Friday. https://t.co/h1DeXp41mN

Before Russia invaded Ukraine, Donald Trump called President Vladimir Putin's wartime strategy "pretty smart." Now, pro-Putin sentiment has spread across social media, right-wing podcasts, Telegram and some conservative media. https://t.co/PC5cj3L5Qd

The Biden administration said on Friday that Russia was never serious about finding a diplomatic solution to the crisis over Ukraine, and that weeks of back-and-forth between Washington and Moscow amounted to a sham as the Kremlin prepared for war. https://t.co/mRDdrkJ8Tq

The Ukrainian defense forces, outmanned and outgunned, waged a ferocious resistance to the Russian invasion on Saturday, battling to keep control of the capital, Kyiv, and other cities around the country. Follow updates from our reporters in Ukraine.
https://t.co/yfrlepUJ6s

With a mix of outrage and sadness, hundreds of Ukrainian New Yorkers responded to the Russian invasion of Ukraine by gathering in Midtown Manhattan on Thursday to denounce the attack. https://t.co/MOe1fgn1jQ

Satellite images collected on Friday show more than 90 helicopters lined up in Belarus, 90 miles from Kyiv. There are attack and transport helicopters, the same types seen Thursday in Russia’s assault on an airport outside the Ukrainian capital. https://t.co/KyTdqUg4oQ

Once Russia's sweeping attacks began on Thursday, the war became unavoidably tangible for Ukrainians — a hovering cloud of darkness that once seemed unimaginable in the post-Cold War era. See what photographers around Ukraine have captured on the ground. https://t.co/NKfq5jMkgs

Egypt imports most of its wheat from Ukraine and Russia. Tunisia was already struggling to pay for grain imports. As Ukrainians suffer during the invasion, the upheaval threatens to further strain economies across the Middle East as well. https://t.co/jY9AvLJJ3v

The failed Chernobyl nuclear power plant in Ukraine as well as the nation’s 15 operating reactors are safe and secure amid Russia’s invasion, according to nuclear experts and the International Atomic Energy Agency, an arm of the UN. https://t.co/WyD7KddlNs

Congressional Democrats on Friday said they would introduce a bill to penalize Russia for its invasion of Ukraine and ensure that President Vladimir Putin and other Russian elites could not benefit from the international trading system. https://t.co/XStJc1xzbH
Maps: Tracking the Russian invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/S2IZCecviB

Several New York landmarks are being illuminated in blue and yellow, the colors of the Ukrainian flag, through the weekend as a show of solidarity for the people of Ukraine, Gov. Kathy Hochul said on Friday. https://t.co/y2agHntm0l

A day after he was removed from conducting at Carnegie Hall, Valery Gergiev faced rising anger for his record of support for Vladimir Putin, with several European institutions threatening to cut ties with him unless he opposed Russia's invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/NnIwbxumtX

Videos verified by The New York Times showed vehicles on fire in the Kyiv neighborhood of Shuliavka, near the city’s zoo, as fighting was reported in the city on Saturday morning.
Follow live updates. https://t.co/luJeRW4V7P

Volunteer fighters armed with assault rifles patrolled central Kyiv on Friday, ready to defend their country.
Follow live updates. https://t.co/hQc2wYb6r0 https://t.co/n2B2lPrgVL

With Russia's full-scale assault of Ukraine in its second day, Russian forces entered Kyiv, pressing closer to the heart of the Ukrainian government.
Follow the latest on the invasion here. https://t.co/mgtYoCpMXW https://t.co/pq3TKe8owO

Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, who was nominated on Friday by President Biden to the Supreme Court, paid homage in her remarks to Judge Constance Baker Motley, the first Black woman ever to be appointed as a federal judge. https://t.co/iuIntbogMl https://t.co/l6fYYFBD7H

President Biden on Friday nominated Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson to the Supreme Court. If confirmed, she would make history by becoming the first Black woman to serve as a justice. In remarks with Biden, Judge Jackson emphasized her faith and her family. https://t.co/5Rou3Gn4D0 https://t.co/pZJ5NqTgLh

President Volodymyr Zelensky said “the fate of Ukraine is now being decided” in a video address to his country.
Follow our live updates. https://t.co/QrwSJFt9xe

Social media videos and news footage from Friday depict the scope of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and the toll it is taking on its citizens.
Follow our live updates. https://t.co/ec4M6VC23i https://t.co/Uge7TFsuhU

50,000 people have fled Ukraine in the past 48 hours according to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, the U.S. ambassador to the UN said. "We have a solemn obligation to not look away." https://t.co/5j1wsw5elD
Breaking News: Russia vetoed a United Nations Security Council resolution that would have condemned the country’s invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/AkjZDNKK0R

Canada's deputy prime minister, Chrystia Freeland, whose mother was Ukrainian-Canadian, said that President Vladimir Putin had cemented his place “in the ranks of the reviled European dictators who caused such carnage in the 20th century.” https://t.co/7b5wedB8kP https://t.co/107HqGJEKH

The body of a Russian soldier lay next to an armored vehicle that Ukrainian soldiers said was Russian, in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Friday.
Ukraine’s military was waging a fierce battle to push Russian forces back from the city a day after a vicious fight. https://t.co/E3ld2rfsqy https://t.co/cMJhxyb3C2

Volunteer fighters are now patrolling central Kyiv after President Volodymyr Zelensky’s call for Ukrainians to defend their country.
Follow the latest on Russia's invasion of Ukraine here: https://t.co/FmlvmFFRYN https://t.co/HACJVpXspA

"The president is here." President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine posted a video on social media showing him standing alongside other government officials, saying that the country’s leaders had not fled Kyiv as Russian forces entered the city. https://t.co/VPxc01QGAG https://t.co/F91xlEp7we

Before Russia invaded Ukraine, Donald Trump called President Vladimir Putin's wartime strategy "pretty smart." Now, pro-Putin sentiment has spread across social media, right-wing podcasts, Telegram and some conservative media. https://t.co/bpI4jO9v2h
Breaking News: The U.S. is planning to levy sanctions against Vladimir Putin as soon as today, an official said, following a similar move from the E.U. https://t.co/n0h06kHSKv

The Russian attack on Ukraine has prompted a flurry of activity among far-right European militia leaders, who are raising funds, recruiting fighters and planning travel to the front lines to confront the country’s invaders, according to a research group. https://t.co/EscFZyMozi

President Volodymyr Zelensky asked Israel's prime minister to mediate negotiations between Ukraine and Russia. "They didn’t say no,” the Ukrainian ambassador to Israel said. "They are trying to figure out where they are in this chess play." https://t.co/p9IKD3jOkA

NATO leaders conducted a rare emergency summit on Friday and agreed to deploy more troops to the eastern members of the alliance. Those deployments would involve thousands of troops, some of them from the U.S., and more than 100 jets put on high alert. https://t.co/VWY3pLieAV
